prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not going to my best friends wedding.
So my best friend (lets call her G) has decided to have her wedding, that's awesome and I'm happy she found the one. 

The issue is G never sent out save the dates, meaning last week we got the actual wedding invitations for a wedding that is happening in 1 month.  

It will be at her grandmother's Ranch and it seems like a pretty nice wedding. 

here is where the issue started. 

a few months ago me and 3 friends decided to plan a trip to Australia to backpack/sightsee for 2 weeks, the trip starts 2 days before the wedding so we can't go. G knew about the trip as we invited her but I'm geussing she forgot. 
she is mad at all of us for not just cancelling the trip and being at her wedding. 

all of us are not super rich so this would be a huge loss if we cancelled the trip. (so we are not) 

I also want to add that she invited 50 people, I asked. and only 20 can make it as she gave 1 month notice. 

she is flipping her shit and acting like we should drop everything for her. 

AITA for not just cancelling my 2 week trip to go to her wedding? 
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author of the AITA post is in the wrong for not attending their best friend's wedding. The situation is that the friend, G, didn't send out save-the-dates and only sent invites a month before the wedding. The author and three friends had already planned a trip to Australia that starts two days before the wedding. They were invited to the trip but G forgot about it. The author is questioning if they're wrong for not canceling the trip, which would be a huge financial loss.

First, I need to consider the timeline. Save-the-dates are usually sent out months in advance to help guests plan. G didn't send those, so maybe she didn't give enough notice. The invitations came just a month before the wedding, which is quite short. The author and friends had planned their trip earlier, so they had a legitimate commitment that conflicts with the wedding. 

G knew about the trip and was invited, but she apparently forgot or didn't consider the timing when planning her wedding. The author mentions that only 20 out of 50 invited guests can attend due to the short notice, which shows that many people have conflicts. So, the author isn't alone in not being able to attend.

Financial constraints are a big factor here. Cancelling the trip would mean a significant financial loss, so the author isn't in a position to drop everything. The friend's reaction seems unreasonable given the short notice and the existing plans. 

In terms of responsibility, the author isn't at fault because the wedding was planned without proper notice. They made an effort to plan a trip that conflicts, and they can't afford to cancel. G should have considered that when sending out invites. So, the answer would be B, the author is not in the wrong.
